Serrano, Sr. |established_date = <!-- Area------------------> |area_magnitude = | unit_pref =US | area_footnotes = <ref>[http://www.census.gov/geo/www/gazetteer/files/Gaz_places_national.txt U.S. Census]</ref> | area_total_sq_mi = 8.914 | area_land_sq_mi = 8.874 | area_water_sq_mi = 0.040 | area_total_km2 = 23.088 | area_land_km2 = 22.985 | area_water_km2 = 0.103 | area_water_percent = 0.45 | area_note = |elevation_m = 41 |elevation_ft = 135 |coordinates_display = display=inline,title |latd = 33 |latm = 56 |lats = 15 |latNS = N |longd = 118 |longm = 4 |longs = 2 |longEW = W |population_as_of = 2010 |population_total = 16223 |population_density_km2 = auto |timezone = [[Pacific Time Zone|PST]] |utc_offset = -8 |timezone_DST = PDT |utc_offset_DST = -7 |latitude = |longitude = |postal_code_type = [[ZIP code]]s |postal_code = 90605, 90670, 90671 |area_code = [[Area code 562|562]] |blank_name = [[Federal Information Processing Standard|FIPS code]] |blank_info = 06-69154 |blank1_name = [[Geographic Names Information System|GNIS]] feature ID |blank1_info = 1661404 |footnotes = |website = http://www.santafesprings.org/ }} '''Santa Fe Springs''' (Spanish: santaâholy, feâfaith) is a city in [[Los Angeles County, California|Los Angeles County]], [[California]], [[United States]]. It is one of the [[Gateway Cities]] of southeast Los Angeles County. The population was 16,223 at the 2010 census, down from 17,438 at the 2000 census.
==Geography== Santa Fe Springs is located at {{coord|33.937443|-118.067155|type:city_region:US|format=dms|display=inline}}.{{GR|1}}
According to the [[United States Census Bureau]], the city has a total area of {{convert|8.9|sqmi|km2}}. {{convert|8.9|sqmi|km2}} of it is land and {{convert|0.04|sqmi|km2}} of it (0.45%) is water.
It is bordered by the unincorporated [[West Whittier-Los Nietos, California|West Whittier-Los Nietos]] to the north, [[Pico Rivera, California|Pico Rivera]] to the northwest, [[Downey, California|Downey]] to the west, [[Norwalk, California|Norwalk]] to the southwest, [[Cerritos, California|Cerritos]] to the south, [[La Mirada, California|La Mirada]] and the unincorporated [[South Whittier, California|South Whittier]] to the east, and [[Whittier, California|Whittier]] to the northeast.
==Demographics== {{USCensusPop | 1960=16342 | 1970=14750 | 1980=14520 | 1990=15520 | 2000=17438 | 2010=16223 | footnote=source:<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.census.gov/prod/www/abs/decennial/index.html |title=CENSUS OF POPULATION AND HOUSING (1790-2000) |publisher=[[U.S. Census Bureau]] |accessdate=2010-07-30}}</ref> }} ===2010=== The [[2010 United States Census]]<ref>{{USCensus-2010CA}}</ref> reported that Santa Fe Springs had a population of 16,223. The [[population density]] was 1,819.9 people per square mile (702.7/kmÂ²). The racial makeup of Santa Fe Springs was 9,514 (58.6%) [[White (U.S. Census)|White]], 371 (2.3%) [[African American (U.S. Census)|African American]], 233 (1.4%) [[Native American (U.S. Census)|Native American]], 677 (4.2%) [[Asian (U.S. Census)|Asian]], 31 (0.2%) [[Pacific Islander (U.S. Census)|Pacific Islander]], 4,712 (29.0%) from [[Race (United States Census)|other races]], and 685 (4.2%) from two or more races. [[Hispanic (U.S. Census)|Hispanic]] or [[Latino (U.S. Census)|Latino]] of any race were 13,137 persons (81.0%).
The Census reported that 16,030 people (98.8% of the population) lived in households, 85 (0.5%) lived in non-institutionalized group quarters, and 108 (0.7%) were institutionalized.
There were 4,747 households, out of which 2,093 (44.1%) had children under the age of 18 living in them, 2,354 (49.6%) were [[marriage|opposite-sex married couples]] living together, 965 (20.3%) had a female householder with no husband present, 368 (7.8%) had a male householder with no wife present. There were 286 (6.0%) [[POSSLQ|unmarried opposite-sex partnerships]], and 26 (0.5%) [[same-sex partnerships|same-sex married couples or partnerships]]. 894 households (18.8%) were made up of individuals and 526 (11.1%) had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 3.38. There were 3,687 [[family (U.S. Census)|families]] (77.7% of all households); the average family size was 3.84.
The population was spread out with 4,286 people (26.4%) under the age of 18, 1,770 people (10.9%) aged 18 to 24, 4,272 people (26.3%) aged 25 to 44, 3,735 people (23.0%) aged 45 to 64, and 2,160 people (13.3%) who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 35.3 years. For every 100 females there were 93.0 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 90.0 males.
There were 4,976 housing units at an average density of 558.2 per square mile (215.5/kmÂ²), of which 2,894 (61.0%) were owner-occupied, and 1,853 (39.0%) were occupied by renters. The homeowner vacancy rate was 2.1%; the rental vacancy rate was 5.5%. 10,323 people (63.6% of the population) lived in owner-occupied housing units and 5,707 people (35.2%) lived in rental housing units.
===2000=== As of the [[census]]{{GR|2}} of 2000, there were 17,438 people, 4,834 households, and 3,780 families residing in the city. The [[population density]] was 1,992.0 inhabitants per square mile (769.5/kmÂ²). There were 4,933 housing units at an average density of 563.5 per square mile (217.7/kmÂ²). The racial makeup of the city was 51.22% [[White (U.S. Census)|White]], 3.89% [[African American (U.S. Census)|African American]], 1.43% [[Native American (U.S. Census)|Native American]], 3.95% [[Asian (U.S. Census)|Asian]], 0.20% [[Pacific Islander (U.S. Census)|Pacific Islander]], 34.99% from [[Race (United States Census)|other races]], and 4.31% from two or more races. [[Hispanic (U.S. Census)|Hispanic]] or [[Latino (U.S. Census)|Latino]] of any race were 71.38% of the population.
As of 2000, speakers of [[Spanish language|Spanish]] as their [[first language]] accounted for 51.63% of residents, while [[English language|English]] was spoken by 46.07%, [[Tagalog language|Tagalog]] was spoken by 1.05%, [[Vietnamese language|Vietnamese]] was spoken by 0.68%, [[Korean language|Korean]] was spoken by 0.37%, [[French language|French]] by 0.17% of the population.<ref name="MLALanguage">{{cite web |url=http://www.mla.org/map_data_results&state_id=6&county_id=&mode=&zip=&place_id=69154&cty_id=&ll=&a=&ea=&order=r |title=Data Center Results - Santa Fe Springs, California] |publisher=[[Modern Language Association]] |accessdate=2009-11-18}}</ref>
There were 4,834 households out of which 38.3% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 54.0% were [[Marriage|married couples]] living together, 18.1% had a female householder with no husband present, and 21.8% were non-families. 18.3% of all households were made up of individuals and 11.2% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 3.35 and the average family size was 3.82.
In the city the population was spread out with 29.1% under the age of 18, 9.4% from 18 to 24, 29.7% from 25 to 44, 19.1% from 45 to 64, and 12.8% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 33 years. For every 100 females there were 100.1 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 97.4 males.
The median income for a household in the city was $44,540, and the median income for a family was $49,867. Males had a median income of $33,413 versus $27,279 for females. The [[per capita income]] for the city was $14,547. About 8.0% of families and 12.5% of the population were below the [[poverty line]], including 13.9% of those under age 18 and 7.6% of those age 65 or over.
==Politics== In the [[California State Legislature|state legislature]] Santa Fe Springs is located in the 30th [[California State Senate|Senate]] District, represented by Democrat [[Ronald S. Calderon]], and in the 56th [[California State Assembly|Assembly]] District, represented by Democrat [[Tony Mendoza]]. Federally, Santa Fe Springs is located in [[California's 38th congressional district]], which has a [[Cook Partisan Voting Index|Cook PVI]] of D +20<ref>{{cite web | title = Will Gerrymandered Districts Stem the Wave of Voter Unrest? | publisher = Campaign Legal Center Blog | url=http://www.clcblog.org/blog_item-85.html | accessdate = 2008-02-10}}</ref> and is represented by Democrat [[Grace Napolitano]], whose office is also in the city of Santa Fe Springs.
==Emergency services== Police services for the city are contracted to the [[Whittier, California|Whittier]] Police Department, based at the Santa Fe Springs Police Services Center sub-station.<ref>http://www.whittierpd.org/wpdsfs.htm</ref> The police services center is located on Telegraph Road.
Fire protection in the city is provided by the Santa Fe Springs Department of Fire-Rescue with ambulance transport by [[Care Ambulance Service]]. There are 4 fire stations in Santa Fe Springs. The headquarters fire station is located on Greenstone Avenue south of Lakeland Boulevard, and also the home of the [[Rio Hondo Fire Academy]].
==Economy== The economy of Santa Fe Springs is largely made up of light industry, unlike its neighboring cities. This is evident when looking at satellite and aerial photography, where the majority of the city is distinguishable from its neighboring cities, due to the density of very large, industrial and manufacturing facilities.
Santa Fe Springs is home to [[Egge Machine Company]],<ref>For instance, ''Street Rodder'', 12/98, p.39.</ref> supplier of [[Cadillac]] engine parts for [[custom car]]s and [[hot rod]]s and also is home to [[U.S. Aerospace]], a publicly traded aerospace and defense contractor for the USDoD, USAF, Lockheed Martin Corporation, The Boeing Company, L-3 Communications Holdings, the Middle River Aircraft Systems subsidiary of General Electric Company, and other aircraft manufacturers, aerospace companies, and defense contractors.<ref>[http://www.usaerospace.com/about-usaerospace About US Aerospace]</ref>
The [[Hathaway Ranch Museum]] in Santa Fe Springs houses an extensive collection of early ranching and farming equipment, as well as oil field machinery. The museum traces five generations of the Hathaway family and is a reflection of the economic transition of the region.<ref>âItâs an original,â Long Beach ââPress-Telegram,ââ Jul. 26, 1999.</ref><ref>âMuseum shows early life in city,â Long Beach ââPress-Telegram,ââ Mar. 26, 2005.</ref>
